awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Studies of the Properties of B-III-N Wide-Bandgap Semiconductor Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This collaborative research project studies an underexplored semiconductor materials system that involves boron incorporation in the four-element alloys of BAlGaN. These materials are a new generation of III-V alloy system compared to the AlInGaN alloys that have been developed to provide high-efficiency lighting. The solid-state illumination and lighting technology, based upon AlInGaN alloys, has found wide practical applications in automotive, liquid-crystal-display back panel, mobile communications and signage illumination, and will soon dominate in general lighting.  However, there are still important limitations for AlInGaN alloy materials. This research project explores the advantages of incorporation of boron into these alloys with the ultimate goal to achieve better strain matching in heterostructures, higher efficiency and potentially p-type doping in the new alloy system. The research is integrated with the educational activities including research training for graduate and undergraduate students in the growth, characterization, and processing of these novel materials, and various outreach programs at both Georgia Institute of Technology and Arizona State University.

Technical Description: The primary focus of this research project is to study the physical, chemical, and electronic properties of high-quality thin films of boron-containing III-nitride semiconductor ternary and quaternary alloys in the technologically important range of compositions and to develop an in-depth understanding of fundamental materials science for improved optoelectronic device designs. The research team uses advanced metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) epitaxial film growth systems, and performs in-depth studies of the effects of growth conditions, substrate materials, substrate orientation, and doping. The materials properties are studied in detail using state-of-the-art nanoscale characterization tools: the crystal structure is studied using atomic-resolution aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy; the electronic band structure is determined by electron holography; and the optical properties are measured by cathodoluminescence with high spatial- and temporal-resolution. Exploring the effects of compositional homogeneity, phase separation, and piezoelectric fields is also included in the research. The microstructural properties are correlated with the optoelectronic properties to understand the role of growth parameters on overall device performance.

por.por_cntn:
The wurtzite BAlN alloy is promising material suitable for deep UV optoelectronic application when adding it into the conventional III-N semiconductor material system; however, it was not sufficiently studied before we embarked this project. With limited funding support, we have demonstrated technical breakthroughs by developping much more stable metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) technique to achieve thick wurtzite BAlN layers, and discovered significant fundamental properties for these BAlN alloys. These works will lay down solid foundation for the device applications of the materials. Specially, we have accomplished the following:

 

1. We have demonstrated the growth of 100nm thick monocrystalline wurtzite BxAl1-xN (x up to 14.4%) ternary alloy on AlN/sapphire, the highest boron composition reported to date. A record-high growth precursor efficiency of 2000 µm/mol was obtained as well. This breakthrough was highlighted by Compound Semiconductor magazine.

Key reference: “Growing Thicker, More Boron-rich BAlN,” X. Li, S. Wang, H. Liu, F. A. Ponce, T. Detchprohm, R. D. Dupuis “100-nm thick single-phase wurtzite BAlN films with boron contents over 10%,” Phys. Status Solidi B 254 (8), 1600749 (2017).

Media highlight: https://compoundsemiconductor.net/article/100877-growing-thicker,-more-boron-rich-baln.html

 

2. We have performed the measurement and analysis of band offset and polarization charge of BAlN/III-nitride heterojunction, where we discovered the largest conduction band offset known to the III-nitride community. This is a significant property that can be applied to both optoelectronic and electronic devices. Thus, it was highlighted as the Work of the Week in the weekly newsletter of Compound Semiconductor magazine.

Key reference: H. Sun, Y. Park, K.-H. Li, C. G. T. Castanedo, A. S. Alowayed, T. Detchprohm, R. D. Dupuis, and X. Li, “Band alignment of B0.14Al0.86N / Al0.7Ga0.3N heterojunction,” Appl. Phys. Lett. 111(12), 122106 (2017).

Media highlight: “Researchers Discover Unique BAlN Properties,” https://compoundsemiconductor.net/article/102580/Researchers_Discover_Unique_BAlN_Properties

 

3. We have conducted detailed structural analysis for the BAlN layers grown by various B/III vapor molar ratio. We found that the boron was efficiently incorporated in the layer but tended to segregate at higher boron content. Also for the first time, we observed twin structure formation in the BAlN alloy at higher boron content. This result would be crucial for the optimization of growth processes for such alloy.

Key reference: S. Wang, X. Li, A. M. Fischer, T. Detchprohm, R. D. Dupuis, and F. A. Ponce, “Crystal structure of BAlN thin films: effect of boron concentration in the gas flow,” J. Cryst. Growth 475, 334 (2017).

 

4. For the first time, we have performed the refractive index measurement of monocrystalline wurtzite BAlN layers with different boron contents. The results show rapid index decrease with increasing boron content, which indicate that BAlN would be a promising candidate for the UV distributed Bragg reflector (DBR) application.

Key reference: K. H. Li, N. Alfaraj, M. S. Alias, T. K. Ng, B. S. Ooi, T. Detchprohm, R. D. Dupuis, and X. Li, “Refractive index measurement of single-crystalline wurtzite BAlN with Boron contents up to 11.6%”, 2016 International Conference on Metalorganic Vapor Phase Deposition (ICMOVPE), San Diego, CA, United States, July 2016.

 

5. We have performed the growth of UV DBR based on BAlN/AlGaN and BAlN/AlN superlattices. For 20 pairs of B0.055Al0.945N/AlN DBR, grown on AlN/sapphire templates, we observed a reflectivity of 61% for a center wavelength of 325 nm; however, the reflectivity gradually decreased to ~40% for a center wavelength of 263nm while a simulated peak reflectivity was estimated to be ~75% for these peak wavelengths.  For a 20-pair B0.055Al0.945N/Al0.70Ga0.30N DBR, the reflectivity reached 86% for a center wavelength of 334nm; however, the reflectivity also decreased as the center wavelength was shifted toward shorter wavelength, e.g., 44% for 259nm.  Such reduction in reflectivity was associated by optical absorption loss via mid gap defects.

Key reference: K. H. Li, N. Alfaraj, M. S. Alias, T. K. Ng, B. S. Ooi, T. Detchprohm, R. D. Dupuis, and X. Li, “Refractive index measurement of single-crystalline wurtzite BAlN with Boron contents up to 11.6%”, 2016 International Conference on Metalorganic Vapor Phase Deposition (ICMOVPE), San Diego, CA, United States, July 2016.
